Identification.LongTitle: An Act to provide services, assistance and compensation to or in respect of Canadian Forces members and veterans and to make amendments to certain Acts
Identification.ShortTitle: Canadian Forces Members and Veterans Re-establishment and Compensation Act
Identification.RunningHead: Canadian Forces Members and Veterans Re-establishment and Compensation

Provision.Text: Her Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate and House of Commons of Canada, enacts as follows:

Section.Text: This Act may be cited as the Canadian Forces Members and Veterans Re-establishment and Compensation Act.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Act.

Definition.Text: aggravated by service, in respect of an injury or a disease, means an injury or a disease that has been aggravated, if the aggravation

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: was attributable to or was incurred during special duty service; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: arose out of or was directly connected with service in the Canadian Forces. (due au service)

Definition.Text: Board means the Veterans Review and Appeal Board established by section 4 of the Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act. (Tribunal)
Canadian Forces means the armed forces referred to in section 14 of the National Defence Act, and includes any predecessor naval, army or air forces of Canada or Newfoundland. (Forces canadiennes)

common-law partner, in relation to a member or a veteran, means a person who is cohabiting with the member or veteran in a conjugal relationship, having so cohabited for a period of at least one year. (conjoint de fait)

compensation means any of the following benefits under this Act, namely, an earnings loss benefit, a supplementary retirement benefit, a Canadian Forces income support benefit, a permanent impairment allowance, a retirement income security benefit, a critical injury benefit, a disability award, a death benefit, a clothing allowance, a detention benefit or a family caregiver relief benefit. (indemnisation)
dependent child, in relation to a member or a veteran, means their child, or a child of their spouse or common-law partner who is ordi­narily residing in the member’s or veteran’s household, who is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under the age of 18 years;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: under the age of 25 years and following a course of instruction approved by the Minister; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: over the age of 18 years and prevented by physical or mental incapacity from earning a livelihood, if the incapacity occurred

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: before the child attained the age of 18 years, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: after the age of 18 years and before the age of 25 years while the child was following a course of instruction approved by the Minister. (enfant à charge)

Definition.Text: disability means the loss or lessening of the power to will and to do any normal mental or physical act. (invalidité)
medical assistance in dying has the same meaning as in section 241.1 of the Criminal Code. (aide médicale à mourir)
medical rehabilitation includes any physical or psychological treatment whose object is to stabilize and restore the basic physical and psychological functions of a person. (réadaptation médicale)
member means an officer or a non-commissioned member of the Canadian Forces, as those terms are defined in subsection 2(1) of the National Defence Act. (militaire)
Minister means the Minister of Veterans Affairs. (ministre)

orphan, in relation to a deceased member or a deceased veteran, means their child, or a child of their survivor who at the time of the member’s or veteran’s death was ordinarily residing in the member’s or veteran’s household, who is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under the age of 18 years;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: under the age of 25 years and following a course of instruction approved by the Minister; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: over the age of 18 years and prevented by physical or mental incapacity from earning a livelihood, if the incapacity occurred

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: before the child attained the age of 18 years, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: after the age of 18 years and before the age of 25 years while the child was following a course of instruction approved by the Minister. (orphelin)

Definition.Text: personal information has the same meaning as in section 3 of the Privacy Act. (renseignements personnels)
prescribed means prescribed by regulation.

psycho-social rehabilitation includes any psychological or social intervention whose object is to restore a person to a state of independent functioning and to facilitate their social adjustment. (réadaptation psychosociale)
rehabilitation services means all services related to the medical rehabilitation, psycho-social rehabilitation and vocational rehabilitation of a person. (services de réadaptation)
service-related injury or disease means an injury or a disease that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: was attributable to or was incurred during special duty service; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: arose out of or was directly connected with service in the Canadian Forces. (liée au service)

Definition.Text: special duty service means service as a member in a special duty area designated under section 69, or as a member as part of a special duty operation designated under section 70, during the period in which the designation is in effect. It includes any of the following that occurred during that period but not earlier than September 11, 2001:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: periods of training for the express purpose of service in that area or as part of that operation, wherever that training takes place;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: travel to and from the area, the operation or the location of training referred to in paragraph (a); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: authorized leave of absence with pay during that service, wherever that leave is taken. (service spécial)

Definition.Text: survivor, in relation to a deceased member or a deceased veteran, means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: their spouse who was, at the time of the member’s or veteran’s death, residing with the member or veteran; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person who was, at the time of the member’s or veteran’s death, the member’s or veteran’s common-law partner. (survivant)

Definition.Text: veteran means a former member. (vétéran)

vocational assistance includes employability assessments, career counselling, training, job-search assistance and job-finding assistance, whose object is to help a person to find appropriate employment. (assistance professionnelle)

vocational rehabilitation includes any process designed to identify and achieve an appropriate occupational goal for a person with a physical or a mental health problem, given their state of health and the extent of their education, skills and experience. (réadaptation professionnelle)

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Act, a spouse is deemed to be residing with a member or a veteran, and a person does not cease to be a member’s or a veteran’s common-law partner, if it is established that they are living apart by reason only of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one or both of them having to reside in a health care facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: circumstances of a temporary nature; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: other circumstances not within the control of the member or veteran or the spouse or common-law partner.

Subsection.Text: A reference in this Act to a member’s or a veteran’s spouse is a reference to a member’s or a veteran’s spouse who is residing with the member or veteran.
This Act does not apply to a member’s or a veteran’s surviving spouse if the member or veteran dies within one year after the date of the marriage, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the opinion of the Minister, the member or veteran was at the time of that marriage in such a condition of health as to justify their having an expectation of life of at least one year; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at the time of the member’s or veteran’s death, the spouse was cohabiting with the member or veteran in a conjugal relationship, having so cohabited for a period of at least one year.

Subsection.Text: This Act does not apply in respect of a member’s or a veteran’s physical or mental health problem, disability or death if it is caused by a wilful self-inflicted injury or improper conduct on the member’s or veteran’s part, including wilful disobedience of an order and vicious or criminal conduct.

For the purposes of this Act, a member or veteran has neither inflicted wilful self-injury nor engaged in improper conduct by reason only that they receive medical as­sistance in dying, if the requirement set out in paragraph 241.2(3)(a) of the Criminal Code has been met.

For the purposes of this Act, if a member or a veteran receives medical assistance in dying, that member or veteran is deemed to have died as a result of the illness, disease or disability for which they were determined to be eligible to receive that assistance, in accordance with paragraph 241.2(3)(a) of the Criminal Code.

Section.Text: The purpose of this Act is to recognize and fulfil the obligation of the people and Government of Canada to show just and due appreciation to members and veterans for their service to Canada. This obligation includes providing services, assistance and compensation to members and veterans who have been injured or have died as a result of military service and extends to their spouses or common-law partners or survivors and orphans. This Act shall be liberally interpreted so that the recognized obligation may be fulfilled.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, provide career transition services to a member or a veteran who meets the prescribed eligibility requirements if the Minister is satisfied that the member or veteran requires assistance in making the transition to the civilian labour force.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Assistance to spouses, common-law partners and survivors
Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, provide career transition services to a member’s or a veteran’s spouse, common-law partner or survivor if the spouse, common-law partner or survivor meets the prescribed eligibility requirements.

The Minister shall, on approving an application made under section 3, assess the needs of the member, veteran, spouse, common-law partner or survivor with respect to career counselling, job-search training and job-finding assistance.
The Minister may develop and implement a career transition plan to address the needs that are identified in the assessment.
In developing a career transition plan, the Minister shall have regard to any prescribed principles.

Section.Text: The Minister may refuse to provide career transition services to a person under this Part to the extent that the person is entitled to receive those types of services from another organization or body.

Heading.Label: PART 2
Heading.TitleText: Rehabilitation Services, Vocational Assistance and Financial Benefits

Section.Text: This Part does not apply in respect of a physical or a mental health problem that resulted primarily from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: service in the Canadian Forces on or before April 1, 1947; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: service in the Korean War, as that term is defined in subsection 3(1) of the Pension Act.

Section.Text: For the purposes of this Part, an injury or a disease is deemed to be a service-related injury or disease if the injury or disease is, in whole or in part, a consequence of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a service-related injury or disease;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a non-service related injury or disease that was aggravated by service;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an injury or a disease that is itself the consequence of an injury or a disease described in paragraph (a) or (b); or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an injury or a disease that is a consequence of an injury or a disease described in paragraph (c).

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, provide rehabilitation services to a veteran who has a physical or a mental health problem resulting primarily from service in the Canadian Forces that is creating a barrier to re-establishment in civilian life.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Factors that the Minister may consider
Subsection.Text: In deciding whether a veteran has a physical or a mental health problem that is creating a barrier to re-establishment in civilian life, and whether that health problem resulted primarily from service in the Canadian Forces, the Minister may consider any factors that the Minister considers relevant, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: medical reports or records that document the veteran’s physical or mental health problem;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: documentation that indicates the nature of the veteran’s service in the Canadian Forces;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: documentation provided by the veteran as to the circumstances of their health problem; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: research that establishes the prevalence of specific health problems in military populations.

Subsection.Text: A veteran’s physical or mental health problem is deemed to have resulted primarily from service in the Canadian Forces if, as a result of the health problem, the veteran suffers from a disability for which a disability award has been paid under section 45 or a pension has been granted under the Pension Act.

The Minister may, on application, provide rehabilitation services or vocational assistance to a veteran who has been released on medical grounds in accordance with chapter 15 of the Queen’s Regulations and Orders for the Canadian Forces.

The Minister shall refuse to consider an application that is made more than 120 days after the day on which the veteran was released, unless the Minister is of the opinion that the reasons for the delay are reasonable in the circumstances.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of a veteran who was within a prescribed class at the time that the physical or mental health problem leading to the release manifested itself.

The Minister shall, on approving an application made under section 8 or 9, assess the veteran’s medical, psycho-social and vocational rehabilitation needs. In the case of a veteran who has applied under section 9, if no rehabilitation needs are identified, the Minister shall assess the veteran’s vocational assistance needs.
The Minister may develop and implement a rehabilitation plan to address the rehabilitation needs that are identified in the assessment.
The only physical and mental health problems that may be addressed in the reha­bilitation plan are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a veteran who was released on medical grounds, the physical or mental health problem for which the veteran was released; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, a physical or a mental health problem resulting primarily from service in the Canadian Forces that is creating a barrier to re-establishment in civilian life.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may develop and implement a vocational assistance plan to address the vocational assistance needs that are identified in the assessment.
In developing a rehabilitation plan or a vocational assistance plan, the Minister shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have regard to any prescribed principles and factors; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be guided by current research in the fields of rehabilitation and vocational assistance.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, provide rehabilitation services and vocational assistance to a veteran’s spouse or common-law partner if the Minister

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has approved an application for rehabilitation services made by or on behalf of the veteran; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has determined, based on an assessment of the veteran under subsection 10(1), that the veteran would not benefit from vocational rehabilitation as a result of being totally and permanently incapacitated by the physical or mental health problem in respect of which the rehabilitation services were approved.

Subsection.Text: If a veteran dies after an application made under subsection (1) has been approved, the survivor continues to be eligible to receive rehabilitation services and vocational assistance under that subsection.

Section.Text: The Minister may, on application, provide rehabilitation services and vocational assistance to a member’s or a veteran’s survivor, if the member or veteran dies as a result of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a service-related injury or disease; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a non-service-related injury or disease that was aggravated by service.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall, on approving an application made under subsection 11(1) or section 12, assess the vocational assistance needs of the spouse, common-law partner or survivor and, if such needs are identified, shall assess the person’s medical, psycho-social and vocational rehabilitation needs.

The Minister may, for the purpose of restoring the earnings capacity of the spouse, common-law partner or survivor to a level that the Minister determines to be reasonable, given the person’s education, skills and experience, develop and implement a vocational assistance plan to address the vocational assistance needs that are identified in the assessment.

The Minister may, to the extent necessary to achieve the purpose set out in subsection (2), develop and implement a rehabilitation plan to address the rehabilitation needs that are identified in the assessment.
In developing a rehabilitation plan or a vocational assistance plan, the Minister shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have regard to any prescribed principles and factors; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be guided by current research in the fields of rehabilitation and vocational assistance.

Subsection.Text: The duration of a rehabilitation plan or a vocational assistance plan shall be fixed by the Minister.
The Minister may evaluate a rehabilitation plan or a vocational assistance plan at any time, and may modify the plan or change its duration.

The Minister may, when evaluating a rehabilitation plan, require the person for whom the plan has been developed to undergo a medical examination or an assessment by a person specified by the Minister.
The Minister may, when evaluating a vocational assistance plan, require a person for whom the plan has been developed to undergo an assessment by a person specified by the Minister.

If a person who is required to undergo a medical examination or an assessment fails without reasonable excuse to do so, the Minister may cancel the rehabilitation plan or the vocational assistance plan.

Section.MarginalNote: Refusal to provide services or assistance

Subsection.Text: The Minister may refuse to provide rehabilitation services or vocational assistance to a person to the extent they are available to the person as an insured service under a provincial health care system, a provincial or federal workers’ compensation plan or any other plan that may be prescribed.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Refusal to provide services or assistance
Subsection.Text: The Minister may refuse to provide rehabilitation services or vocational assistance, in whole or in part, to a person if those services or that assistance has already been provided or if the Minister considers that the refusal is reasonable in the circumstances.

Section.Text: The Minister may cancel a rehabilitation plan or a vocational assistance plan in the prescribed circumstances.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay an earnings loss benefit to a veteran if the Minister determines, as a result of an assessment made in accordance with subsection 10(1), that a rehabilitation plan or a vocational assistance plan should be developed for the veteran.

The earnings loss benefit begins to be payable on the day on which the Minister determines that a rehabilitation plan or a vocational assistance plan should be developed. For greater certainty, if the determination is in respect of a member, the earnings loss benefit is not payable until the day after the day on which the member is released from the Canadian Forces.
Subject to subsection (4) and section 21, the earnings loss benefit is payable to a veteran until the earlier of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the veteran completes the rehabilitation plan or the vocational assistance plan,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the rehabilitation plan or the vocational assistance plan is cancelled, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the veteran attains the age of 65 years.

Subsection.Text: If the Minister determines that the veteran is unable to engage in suitable gainful employment as a result of being totally and permanently incapacitated by the physical or mental health problem for which the rehabilitation plan was developed, the earnings loss benefit continues to be payable to the veteran after the plan has been completed or cancelled until the earlier of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the Minister determines that the veteran is no longer unable to engage in suitable gainful employment as a result of being totally and permanently incapacitated by that health problem, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the veteran attains the age of 65 years.

Subsection.Text: Subject to the regulations, the monthly amount of the earnings loss benefit under section 18 that is payable to a veteran shall be determined in accordance with the formula

FormulaDefinition.Text: is 75% of the veteran’s imputed income for a month; and
is an amount that is payable to the veteran for a month from prescribed sources.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: respecting, for the purposes of subsection (1), the determination of the imputed income in respect of a class of veterans;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing a minimum or a maximum amount of imputed income in respect of a class of veterans;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the periodic adjustment of the value of A and B in subsection (1); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the determination, for the purpose of the value of B in subsection (1), of an amount payable to a veteran for a month.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, for the purpose of determining whether a veteran may continue to receive an earnings loss benefit, require a veteran who, as a result of a determination of total and permanent incapacity, is in receipt of an earnings loss benefit under section 18 — or would, but for their level of income, be in receipt of it — to undergo a medical examination or an assessment by a person specified by the Minister.
If a veteran who is required by the Minister to undergo a medical examination or an assessment fails without reasonable excuse to do so, the Minister may cancel the earnings loss benefit.

Section.Text: The Minister may cancel an earnings loss benefit that is payable under section 18 in the prescribed circumstances.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay, in accordance with section 23, an earnings loss benefit to a member’s or a veteran’s survivor or orphan, if the member or veteran dies as the result of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a service-related injury or disease; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a non-service-related injury or disease that was aggravated by service.

Subsection.Text: The earnings loss benefit begins to be payable on the later of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day after the day of the member’s or veteran’s death, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day that is one year prior to the day on which the application for the benefit is approved in respect of the survivor or orphan, as the case may be.

Subsection.Text: The earnings loss benefit ceases to be payable on the day on which the member or veteran, if alive, would have attained the age of 65 years.

Subject to the regulations, the monthly amount of an earnings loss benefit under section 22 that is payable in respect of a member or a veteran is 75% of the member’s or veteran’s imputed income for a month.
If an earnings loss benefit is payable to a survivor or an orphan, the following rules apply:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if there is a survivor but no orphans, the survivor is entitled to 100% of the earnings loss benefit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if there is a survivor and one or more orphans,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the survivor is entitled to 60% of the earnings loss benefit, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the orphans are entitled, as a class, to 40% of the earnings loss benefit, divided equally among them; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if there are one or more orphans but no survivor, each orphan is entitled to the lesser of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 40% of the earnings loss benefit, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the amount obtained by dividing the earnings loss benefit by the number of those orphans.

Subsection.Text: Subject to the regulations, the monthly amount of the earnings loss benefit that is payable to a survivor shall be reduced by an amount that is payable to the survivor for a month — in respect of the member or veteran — from prescribed sources.
The Governor in Council may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: respecting, for the purposes of subsection (1), the determination of the imputed income in respect of a class of members or veterans;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing a minimum or a maximum amount of imputed income in respect of a class of members or veterans;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the periodic adjustment of an earnings loss benefit calculated in accord­ance with subsection (1) and an amount determined for the purposes of subsection (3); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the determination, for the purpose of subsection (3), of an amount payable to a survivor for a month.

Section.Text: If an earnings loss benefit is payable for only part of a month, the benefit shall be paid pro rata, based on a 30-day month.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a supplementary retirement benefit to a veteran who has been in receipt of an earnings loss benefit in accordance with subsection 18(4) — or would, but for their level of income, have been in receipt of it — if the veteran is no longer entitled to that benefit.
The Minister may, on application, pay a supplementary retirement benefit to a veteran’s survivor if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the veteran, at the time of their death, was in receipt of an earnings loss benefit in accordance with subsection 18(4) or would, but for their level of income, have been in receipt of it; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the survivor is not eligible to receive an earnings loss benefit under section 22.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a supplementary retirement benefit to a member’s or a veteran’s survivor if the survivor has been in receipt of an earnings loss benefit under section 22 but is no longer entitled to that benefit.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the amount of the supplementary retirement benefit payable in respect of any class or classes of veterans or survivors.

The Minister may, on application made within the prescribed time, pay a Canadian Forces income support benefit to a veteran who has been in receipt of an earnings loss benefit under section 18 — or would, but for their level of income, have been in receipt of it — if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the veteran is no longer entitled to the earnings loss benefit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the veteran meets the prescribed employment-related criteria; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the month in which the application is made, a calculation made under subsection 37(1) in respect of the veteran would result in an amount greater than zero.

Section.Text: The Minister may, on application made within the prescribed time, pay a Canadian Forces income support benefit to a veteran’s survivor if the veteran was in receipt of that benefit at the time of their death and if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the veteran dies as the result of an injury or a disease other than an injury or a disease described in paragraph 29(a);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the survivor meets the prescribed employment-related criteria; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the month in which the application is made, a calculation made under subsection 37(1) in respect of the survivor would result in an amount greater than zero.

Section.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a Canadian Forces income support benefit to a member’s or a veteran’s survivor if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the member or veteran dies as a result of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a service-related injury or disease, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a non-service-related injury or disease that was aggravated by service; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the day on which the application is approved, the member or veteran, if alive, would be at least 65 years of age.

Section.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a Canadian Forces income support benefit to a veteran’s orphan if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the veteran dies as a result of an injury or a disease other than an injury or a disease described in paragraph 31(a); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the veteran was in receipt of that benefit at the time of their death.

Section.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a Canadian Forces income support benefit to a member’s or a veteran’s orphan if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the member or veteran dies as a result of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a service-related injury or disease, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a non-service-related injury or disease that was aggravated by service; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the day on which the application is approved, the member or veteran, if alive, would be at least 65 years of age.

Section.Text: The Canadian Forces income support benefit under section 29, 30 or 31 begins to be payable on the later of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the first day of the month after the month in which the member or veteran died, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the first day of the month that is one year prior to the month in which the application for the benefit is approved in respect of the survivor or orphan, as the case may be.

Section.Text: A Canadian Forces income support benefit may be paid to a person only if the person resides in Canada.

If, in a month, a person who is in receipt of a Canadian Forces income support benefit dies or ceases to reside in Canada, the benefit shall be paid as if the person were entitled to the benefit for that entire month.

Subsection.Text: A Canadian Forces income support benefit under section 27 or 28 is only payable for each month that the veteran or survivor participates — to the extent required to meet the objectives of the program — in a career transition services program that is approved by the Minister.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a veteran or a survivor who has attained the age of 65 years.

The Minister may exempt a veteran or a survivor from the application of subsection (1), subject to any terms and conditions that the Minister considers appropriate, and the Minister may cancel the exemption.
Subject to subsection (5), the Canadian Forces income support benefit under section 27 or 28 begins to be payable on the earlier of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the first day of the month in which the veteran or the survivor starts a career transition services program referred to in subsection (1), and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the first day of the month in which the Minister grants the veteran or survivor an exemption under subsection (3).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception — applicant over 65 years of age
Subsection.Text: If an application for a Canadian Forces income support benefit under section 27 or 28 is approved in respect of a veteran or a survivor who has attained the age of 65 years, the benefit begins to be payable on the first day of the month in which the application is approved.
Subject to section 36, a Canadian Forces income support benefit under section 27 or 28 ceases to be payable on the earlier of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the last day of the month in which the veteran or survivor ceases to participate in a career transition services program referred to in subsection (1), unless the veteran or survivor is exempt from the application of that subsection,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the last day of the month in which the veteran or survivor no longer meets the prescribed employment-related criteria, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the last day of the month in which a calculation made under subsection 37(1) in respect of the veteran or survivor would result in an amount equal to or less than zero.

Section.Text: The Minister may suspend the payment of a Canadian Forces income support benefit or cancel the benefit, in the prescribed circumstances.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), the amount of the Canadian Forces income support benefit payable under sections 27 to 31 for each month in a current payment period shall be determined by the formula

FormulaDefinition.Text: is

FormulaParagraph.Label: (a)
FormulaParagraph.Text: in the case of a veteran, the sum of the applicable amounts set out in column 2 of items 1 to 3 of Schedule 1,

FormulaParagraph.Label: (b)
FormulaParagraph.Text: in the case of a survivor, the amount set out in column 2 of item 4 of Schedule 1, and

FormulaParagraph.Label: (c)
FormulaParagraph.Text: in the case of an orphan, the amount set out in column 2 of item 5 of Schedule 1;

FormulaDefinition.Text: is

FormulaParagraph.Label: (a)
FormulaParagraph.Text: in the case of a veteran, 1/12 of the income of the veteran and the veteran’s spouse or common-law partner, if any, for the base calendar year,

FormulaParagraph.Label: (b)
FormulaParagraph.Text: in the case of a survivor, 1/12 of the survivor’s income for the base calendar year, and

FormulaParagraph.Label: (c)
FormulaParagraph.Text: in the case of an orphan, 1/12 of the orphan’s income for the base calendar year; and

FormulaDefinition.Text: is

FormulaParagraph.Label: (a)
FormulaParagraph.Text: in the case of a veteran, the total of the current monthly benefits payable to the veteran and the veteran’s spouse or common-law partner, if any, from prescribed sources,

FormulaParagraph.Label: (b)
FormulaParagraph.Text: in the case of a survivor, the total of the current monthly benefits payable to the survivor from prescribed sources, and

FormulaParagraph.Label: (c)
FormulaParagraph.Text: in the case of an orphan, the total of the current monthly benefits payable to the orphan from prescribed sources.

Subsection.Text: If the spouses or common-law partners are both veterans to whom a Canadian Forces income support benefit is payable, the following rules apply in respect of each veteran:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the value of A in subsection (1) is the sum of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the amount set out in column 2 of item 1 of Schedule 1, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of each dependent child of the veteran, and each dependent child of the veteran’s spouse or common-law partner who is not a dependent child of the veteran, 1/2 of the amount set out in column 2 of item 3 of Schedule 1;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the value of B in subsection (1) is 1/24 of the income of the veteran and the veteran’s spouse or common-law partner for the base calendar year; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the value of C in subsection (1) is 1/2 of the total of the current monthly benefits payable to the veteran and the veteran’s spouse or common-law partner from prescribed sources.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a permanent impairment allowance to a veteran who has one or more physical or mental health problems that are creating a permanent and severe impairment if the veteran, in respect of each of those health problems,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has had an application for rehabilitation services approved under this Part; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has received a disability award under Part 3 or a pension for disability under the Pension Act, or would have received such an award or pension but has not because

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the aggregate of all of the veteran’s disability assessments and deemed disability assessments exceeds 100%, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the disability award is not yet payable because, in the opinion of the Minister, the disability has not stabilized.

Subsection.Text: A veteran who has received or is receiving an exceptional incapacity allowance under the Pension Act is not eligible to be paid a permanent impairment allowance.

The Minister shall determine the amount of the permanent impairment allowance that may be paid to the veteran in a year. The minimum permanent impairment allowance shall be the amount set out in column 2 of item 1 of Schedule 2, and the maximum permanent impairment allowance shall be the amount set out in column 2 of item 2 of that Schedule.

The Minister may, on application, increase the permanent impairment allowance that may be paid under subsection (2) by the amount set out in item 2.1, column 2, of Schedule 2, if the Minister determines that the veteran is totally and permanently incapacitated.

Section.Text: The permanent impairment allowance under subsection 38(2) and an increase to the permanent impairment allowance under subsection 38(3) begin to be payable on the latest of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the application for the allowance or increase, as the case may be, is made;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day that is one year prior to the day on which the application for the allowance or increase, as the case may be, is approved; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the day after the day on which the member is released from the Canadian Forces.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, for the purpose of determining whether a veteran may continue to receive a permanent impairment allowance, require the veteran to undergo a medical examination or an assessment by a person specified by the Minister.
If a veteran who is required by the Minister to undergo a medical examination or an assessment fails without reasonable excuse to do so, the Minister may cancel the permanent impairment allowance.

Section.MarginalNote: Eligibility — veteran eligible for earnings loss benefit

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a retirement income security benefit to a veteran who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has attained the age of 65 years;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the day before the day on which they attained the age of 65 years, was eligible to continue to receive an earnings loss benefit under subsection 18(4); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is eligible for a disability award under section 45 or a disability pension under the Pension Act.

Subsection.Text: The retirement income security benefit begins to be payable on the later of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day after the day on which the veteran attains the age of 65 years, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day that is one year before the day on which the Minister determines that the veteran is entitled to the benefit.

Subsection.Text: The retirement income security benefit ceases to be payable on the last day of the month in which the veteran dies.
Subject to the regulations, the monthly amount of the retirement income security benefit that is payable to a veteran shall be determined in accordance with the formula

FormulaDefinition.Text: is 70% of the earnings loss benefit to which the veteran would be entitled for the month in which they attain the age of 65 years, calculated as if the benefit were payable for that entire month and not taking into account amounts that are payable to the veteran from prescribed sources referred to in subsection 19(1);
is 70% of the permanent impairment allowance, including any increase to it under subsection 38(3), payable to the veteran for the month in which they attain the age of 65 years; and
is the total amount that is payable to the veteran for a month from prescribed sources.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the periodic adjustment of the total value of A and B in subsection (4); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the determination, for the purpose of the value of C in subsection (4), of an amount payable to a veteran for a month.

Section.MarginalNote: Eligibility — veteran in receipt of long-term disability benefit

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a retirement income security benefit to a veteran who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: attained the age of 65 years after March 31, 2006 but before the prescribed date;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the day before the day on which they attained the age of 65 years was, as a result of being totally disabled, in receipt of long-term disability benefits under the Service Income Security Insurance Plan Long Term Disability; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is eligible for a disability award under section 45 or a disability pension under the Pension Act.

Subsection.Text: The retirement income security benefit begins to be payable on the later of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day after the day on which the veteran attains the age of 65 years, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day that is one year before the day on which the Minister determines that the veteran is entitled to the benefit.

Subsection.Text: The retirement income security benefit ceases to be payable on the last day of the month in which the veteran dies.
Subject to the regulations, the monthly amount of the retirement income security benefit that is payable to a veteran shall be determined in accordance with the formula

FormulaDefinition.Text: is 70% of the earnings loss benefit to which the veteran would have been entitled, had the veteran applied, for the month in which they attain the age of 65 years, calculated as if the benefit were payable for that entire month and not taking into account amounts that would have been payable to the veteran from prescribed sources referred to in subsection 19(1);
is 70% of the permanent impairment allowance, including any increase to it under subsection 38(3), payable to the veteran for the month in which they attain the age of 65 years; and
is the total amount that is payable to the veteran for a month from prescribed sources.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the periodic adjustment of the total value of A and B in subsection (4); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the determination, for the purpose of the value of C in subsection (4), of an amount payable to a veteran for a month.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a retirement income security benefit to a veteran’s survivor if the veteran was eligible, or would have been eligible had the veteran applied, for a retirement income security benefit at the time of their death.
The retirement income security benefit begins to be payable on the later of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the first day of the month after the month in which the veteran died, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day that is one year before the day on which the Minister determines that the survivor is entitled to the benefit.

Subsection.Text: The retirement income security benefit ceases to be payable on the last day of the month in which the survivor dies.
Subject to the regulations, the monthly amount of the retirement income security benefit that is payable to a survivor shall be determined in accordance with the formula

FormulaDefinition.Text: is 50% of the retirement income security benefit to which the veteran would be entitled, or would have been entitled had the veteran applied, for the month in which the veteran dies, not taking into account amounts that are payable to the veteran from prescribed sources referred to in the description of C in subsection 40.1(4) or in the description of C in subsection 40.2(4), as the case may be; and
is the total amount payable to the survivor in respect of the veteran for a month from prescribed sources.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the periodic adjustment of the value of A in subsection (4); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the determination, for the purpose of the value of B in subsection (4), of an amount payable to a survivor for a month.

Section.MarginalNote: Eligibility — survivor no longer eligible for earnings loss benefit

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a retirement income security benefit to a member’s or a veteran’s survivor who is no longer eligible to receive an earnings loss benefit under subsection 22(3).
The retirement income security benefit begins to be payable on the later of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day after the day on which the member or the veteran would have attained the age of 65 years, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day that is one year before the day on which the Minister determines that the survivor is entitled to the benefit.

Subsection.Text: The retirement income security benefit ceases to be payable on the last day of the month in which the survivor dies.
Subject to the regulations, the monthly amount of the retirement income security benefit under subsection (1) that is payable to a survivor shall be determined in accordance with the formula

FormulaDefinition.Text: is 70% of the earnings loss benefit that would be payable under subsection 23(1) for the month in which the member or veteran, if alive, would have attained the age of 65 years, calculated as if the benefit were payable for that entire month and not taking into account amounts that are payable to the survivor in respect of the member or veteran from prescribed sources referred to in subsection 23(3); and
is the total amount that is payable to the survivor in respect of the member or veteran for a month from prescribed sources.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the periodic adjustment of the value of A in subsection (4); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the determination, for the purpose of the value of B in subsection (4), of an amount payable to a survivor for a month.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may waive the requirement for an application for the retirement income security benefit if the Minister is satisfied that the veteran or survivor would be eligible for the benefit if they were to apply for it based on information that has been collected or obtained by the Minister in the exercise of the Minister’s powers or the performance of the Minister’s duties and functions in respect of the earnings loss benefit, permanent impairment allowance or disability award or in respect of the disability pension under the Pension Act.
If the Minister intends to waive the requirement for an application, the Minister shall notify the veteran or survivor in writing of that intention.

If the veteran or survivor accepts the waiver of the requirement for an application, the veteran or survivor shall, within the period specified by the Minister, file with the Minister any information requested by the Minister.
The veteran or the survivor may, within the period specified by the Minister, decline a waiver of the requirement for an application by notifying the Minister in writing of their decision to do so.

Even if the Minister intends to waive the requirement for an application, the Minister may require that the veteran or the survivor make an application for the retirement income security benefit and, in that case, the Minister shall notify the veteran or survivor in writing of that requirement.

Section.Text: The Minister may, in the prescribed circumstances, suspend the payment of a retirement income security benefit or cancel the benefit.
The Governor in Council may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the notification of the Minister, by persons who are in receipt of an earnings loss benefit, a Canadian Forces income support benefit or a retirement income security benefit, of any changes in income or benefits, or in an amount payable for a month from a prescribed source for the purposes of subsection 19(1), 23(3), 40.1(4), 40.2(4), 40.3(4) or 40.4(4), requiring the provision of statements of estimated income, benefits or amounts payable and providing for the effect of those changes on the calculation of the amount of the compensation payable;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the determination of what constitutes suitable gainful employment, a barrier to re-establishment in civilian life and total and permanent incapacity;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: defining “base calendar year”, “income” and “payment period” for the purposes of section 37;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the increase of any amount set out in column 2 of Schedule 1 in case of any increase in the amount of a pension or a supplement, as those terms are defined in section 2 of the Old Age Security Act, as a result of amendments to that Act;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the payment of expenses arising out of a person’s participation in a rehabilitation plan or a vocational assistance plan;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: defining residence and defining intervals of absence from Canada that shall be deemed not to have interrupted residence in Canada for the purposes of sections 33 and 34; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: respecting, for the purposes of section 38, what constitutes a permanent and severe impairment, the manner of determining whether a veteran has a permanent and severe impairment and the extent of the permanent and severe impairment.

Heading.Label: PART 3
Heading.TitleText: Critical Injury, Disability, Death and Detention

Section.Text: This Part, other than sections 44.1 to 44.3, does not apply in respect of an injury or a disease, or the aggravation of an injury or a disease, if the injury or disease, or the aggravation, is one for which a pension may be granted under the Pension Act.
In making a decision under this Part or under section 84, the Minister and any person designated under section 67 shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: draw from the circumstances of the case, and any evidence presented to the Minister or person, every reasonable inference in favour of an applicant under this Part or under section 84;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: accept any uncontradicted evidence presented to the Minister or the person, by the applicant, that the Minister or person considers to be credible in the circumstances; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: resolve in favour of the applicant any doubt, in the weighing of the evidence, as to whether the applicant has established a case.

Section.Text: In all proceedings under this Part, an applicant may be represented by a service bureau of a veterans’ organization or, at the applicant’s own expense, by any other representative of the applicant’s choice.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a critical injury benefit to a member or veteran who establishes that they sustained one or more severe and traumatic injuries, or developed an acute disease, and that the injury or disease

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: was a service-related injury or disease;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: was the result of a sudden and single incident that occurred after March 31, 2006; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: immediately caused a severe impairment and severe interference in their quality of life.

Subsection.Text: In deciding whether the impairment and the interference in the quality of life referred to in paragraph (1)(c) were severe, the Minister shall consider any prescribed factors.
The Governor in Council may, for the purpose of subsection 44.1(1), make regulations respecting the determination of what constitutes a sudden and single incident.

Section.Text: The amount of the critical injury benefit that is payable to a member or veteran shall be the amount set out in column 2 of item 2.2 of Schedule 2.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may waive the requirement for an application in subsection 44.1(1) if the Minister is satisfied, based on information that has been collected or obtained by the Minister in the exercise of the Minister’s powers or the performance of the Minister’s duties and functions, including in respect of the disability award or in respect of the disability pension under the Pension Act, that the member or veteran is entitled to the critical injury benefit.
If the Minister intends to waive the requirement for an application, the Minister shall notify the member or veteran in writing of that intention.

If the member or veteran accepts the waiver of the requirement for an application, the member or the veteran shall, within the period specified by the Minister, file with the Minister any information requested by the Minister.
The member or veteran may, within the period specified by the Minister, decline a waiver of the requirement for an application by notifying the Minister in writing of their decision to do so.

Even if the Minister intends to waive the requirement for an application, the Minister may require that the member or veteran make an application for the critical injury benefit and, in that case, the Minister shall notify the member or veteran in writing of that requirement.
The Minister may, on application, pay a disability award to a member or a veteran who establishes that they are suffering from a disability resulting from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a service-related injury or disease; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a non-service-related injury or disease that was aggravated by service.

Subsection.Text: A disability award may be paid under paragraph (1)(b) only in respect of that fraction of a disability, measured in fifths, that represents the extent to which the injury or disease was aggravated by service.
For the purposes of subsection 45(1), an injury or a disease is deemed to be a service-related injury or disease if the injury or disease is, in whole or in part, a consequence of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a service-related injury or disease;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a non-service-related injury or disease that was aggravated by service;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an injury or a disease that is itself a consequence of an injury or a disease described in paragraph (a) or (b); or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an injury or a disease that is a consequence of an injury or a disease described in paragraph (c).

Subsection.Text: If a disability results from an injury or a disease that is deemed to be a service-related injury or disease, a disability award may be paid under subsection 45(1) only in respect of that fraction of the disability, measured in fifths, that represents the extent to which that injury or disease is a consequence of another injury or disease that is, or is deemed to be, a service-related injury or disease.

Section.MarginalNote: Award for loss of paired organ or limb

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay a disability award to a member or a veteran who has received a disability award under section 45 on account of the loss of, or the permanent loss of the use of, one of their paired organs or limbs if the member or veteran suffers, either before or after that loss or loss of use, the loss of, the permanent loss of the use of or the impairment of the other paired organ or limb from any cause whatever.

The member’s or veteran’s extent of disability in respect of that other paired organ or limb shall be considered to be 50% of the extent of disability at which the member or veteran would have been assessed at if the loss of, the permanent loss of the use of or the impairment of that paired organ or limb had occurred in circumstances in which a disability award would have been payable under section 45.

If a member or a veteran to whom a disability award under section 45 or 47 has been paid, in whole or in part, establishes that their extent of disability has subsequently increased, the Minister may, on application, pay a disability award to the member or veteran that corresponds to the extent of that increase.

In the case of a non-service related injury or disease that was aggravated by service, a disability award may be paid under subsection (1) only in respect of that fraction of the disability that has been determined in accord­ance with subsection 45(2).

In the case of an injury or a disease that is a consequence of another injury or disease, the disability award may be paid under subsection (1) only in respect of that fraction of the disability that has been determined in accord­ance with subsection 46(2).

Section.Text: If a member or a veteran dies as a result of an injury or a disease for which a disability award under section 45 has been paid, in whole or in part, or would be payable and their death occurs more than 30 days after the day on which the injury occurred or the disease was contracted or the injury or disease was aggravated, the member or veteran is deemed to have been assessed, at the time of their death, as having an extent of disability at that time of 100%.

Section.MarginalNote: Death of member or veteran — no application made

Subsection.Text: If a member or a veteran who would have been entitled to a disability award under section 45, 47 or 48 dies before they have applied for the award, the Minister may, on application, pay, in accordance with section 55, to a survivor or a person who was, at the time of the member’s or veteran’s death, a dependent child, the disability award to which the member or veteran, had they lived, would have been entitled under section 45, 47 or 48, as the case may be.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Death of member or veteran — application pending
Subsection.Text: If a member or a veteran who has made an application for a disability award under section 45, 47 or 48 dies before the Minister has made a decision in respect of the application, the Minister may pay, in accordance with section 55, to a survivor or a person who was, at the time of the member’s or veteran’s death, a dependent child, the disability award to which the member or veteran, had they lived, would have been entitled under section 45, 47 or 48, as the case may be.

The survivor or child has, in respect of the application referred to in subsection (2), all of the rights that the member or veteran would have had had they lived, other than the right to make an election under subsection 52.1(1).
The assessment of the extent of a disability shall be based on the instructions and a table of disabilities to be made by the Minister for the guidance of persons making those assessments.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Statutory Instruments Act does not apply
Subsection.Text: The instructions and table of disabilities are exempt from the application of sections 3, 5 and 11 of the Statutory Instruments Act.
Subject to section 54, the amount of a disability award payable in respect of a member or a veteran shall be determined by the formula

FormulaDefinition.Text: is the amount set out in column 3 of Schedule 3 that corresponds to the member’s or veteran’s extent of disability, as set out in column 2 of that Schedule, in respect of the aggregate of all of the member’s or veteran’s disability assessments and deemed disability assessments under this Act; and
is the amount set out in column 3 of Schedule 3 in respect of the extent of disability set out in column 2 of that Schedule that corresponds to the difference, if any, between

FormulaParagraph.Label: (a)
FormulaParagraph.Text: the member’s or veteran’s extent of disability, in respect of the aggregate of all of the member’s or veteran’s disability assessments or deemed disability assessments under this Act,

FormulaParagraph.Label: (b)
FormulaParagraph.Text: the member’s or veteran’s extent of disability for which the disability award is to be paid.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of determining the extent of disability in subsection (1), if a disability award may be paid only in respect of a fraction of a disability in accordance with subsection 45(2), 46(2) or 48(2) or (3), then only that fraction of the disability shall be taken into account.

If an amount is paid or payable to a person from a prescribed source in respect of a death or disability for which a disability award is payable, the Minister may reduce the disability award payable to the person by a prescribed amount.

Section.MarginalNote: Election as to payment of award

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (4) and (7), a member or a veteran to whom a disability award is to be paid under section 45, 47 or 48 may elect, within the prescribed time and in the prescribed manner,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to be paid the amount of the disability award as a lump sum;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to be paid each year, in lieu of the amount of the disability award, for up to the number of years indicated by the member or veteran, an amount equal to the amount determined by the formula

FormulaDefinition.Text: is the amount of the disability award,
is the number of years indicated by the member or veteran, and
is the amount of interest for that year determined in accordance with the regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to be paid the portion, indicated by the member or veteran, of the amount of the disability award as a lump sum and to be paid each year, in lieu of the remainder of the amount of the disability award, for up to the number of years indicated by the member or veteran, an amount equal to the amount determined by the formula set out in paragraph (b) read as though the description of A were the amount of the disability award less the portion that the member or veteran elected to be paid as a lump sum.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall, in the prescribed manner, inform the member or veteran of their right to make an election under subsection (1).
If the member or veteran fails to make the election, the amount of the disability award is to be paid as a lump sum.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Lump sum if disability is less than five per cent
Subsection.Text: If the extent of disability for which the disability award is to be paid is less than five per cent of total disability, the amount of the disability award is to be paid as a lump sum.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Election in respect of remaining payments
Subsection.Text: A member or a veteran who has elected to be paid in annual payments and who has received at least one payment may elect, in the prescribed manner, to be paid a lump sum, determined in accordance with the regulations, in lieu of the annual payments remaining to be paid.

A member or a veteran who dies after having elected to be paid in annual payments is deemed to have elected, on the day before their death, to be paid a lump sum, determined in accordance with the regulations, in lieu of the annual payments remaining to be paid.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Member or veteran currently receiving annual payments
Subsection.Text: If a member or a veteran to whom a disability award (in this subsection referred to as the “new disability award”) is to be paid under section 45, 47 or 48 is currently being paid annual payments in respect of another disability award and they make an election referred to in paragraph (1)(b) or (c) in respect of the new award,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of determining the amount of the annual payments in respect of the new disability award,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an election referred to in paragraph (1)(b), the description of A in that paragraph, is, despite that paragraph, the sum of the amount of the new disability award and the amount of the lump sum that the member or veteran would have received had they made an election under subsection (5) in respect of the other disability award, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an election referred to in paragraph (1)(c), the description of A in paragraph (1)(b), despite paragraph (1)(c), is the sum of the amount of the new disability award and the amount of the lump sum that the member or veteran would have received had they made an election under subsection (5) in respect of the other disability award less the portion of the new disability award to be paid to the member or veteran as a lump sum; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no additional payments are to be made in respect of the other disability award.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Amounts deemed to be compensation payable under this Act
Subsection.Text: The amounts determined by the application of paragraphs (1)(b) and (c) and the lump sum referred to in subsection (5) or (6) are deemed to be compensation payable under this Act.

Section.Text: A disability award under section 45, 47 or 48 becomes payable whenever, in the opinion of the Minister, the disability has stabilized.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 45, 47 or 48, if a member’s or a veteran’s extent of disability, in respect of the aggregate of all of the member’s or veteran’s disability assessments and deemed disability assessments, exceeds 100%, no disability award shall be granted in respect of any percentage points exceeding 100%.
Any disability assessments under the Pension Act shall be taken into account for the purpose of determining whether the extent of disability exceeds 100%.

For the purpose of determining the extent of disability, if a disability award may be paid only in respect of a fraction of a disability in accordance with subsection 45(2), 46(2) or 48(2) or (3), or if only a fraction of a disability is pensionable under the Pension Act, then only that fraction of the disability shall be taken into account.

Section.Text: If a disability award is payable to a survivor or a person who was, at the time of a member’s or veteran’s death, a dependent child, the following rules apply:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if there is a survivor but no person who was a dependent child, the survivor is entitled to 100% of the disability award;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if there is a survivor and one or more persons who were dependent children,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the survivor is entitled to 50% of the disability award, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the persons who were dependent children are entitled, as a class, to 50% of the disability award, divided equally among them; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if there are one or more persons who were dependent children but no survivor, each of those children is entitled to the amount obtained by dividing the disability award by the number of those dependent children.

Section.MarginalNote: No award — decision under Pension Act

Subsection.Text: No disability award shall be granted in respect of an injury or a disease, or the aggravation of an injury or a disease, if the injury or disease, or the aggravation, has been the subject of an application for a pension under the Pension Act and the Minister, or the Commission as defined in section 79 of that Act, has rendered a decision in respect of the application.

Subsection.MarginalNote: No award — inseparable for purpose of assessment
Subsection.Text: No disability award shall be granted in respect of an injury or a disease, or the aggravation of an injury or a disease, if the Minister determines that the injury or disease, or the aggravation, is inseparable — for the purpose of assessing the extent of disability — from an injury or a disease, or the aggravation of an injury or a disease, for which a pension has been granted under the Pension Act.
The Minister may, on application, pay, in accordance with section 59, a death benefit to a member’s survivor or a person who was, at the time of the member’s death, a dependent child if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the member dies as a result of a service-related injury or disease; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the member’s death occurs within 30 days after the day on which the injury occurred or the disease was contracted.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Eligibility — injury or disease aggravated by service
Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay, in accordance with section 59, a death benefit to a member’s survivor or a person who was, at the time of the member’s death, a dependent child if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the member dies as a result of a non-service-related injury or disease that was aggravated by service; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the member’s death occurs within 30 days after the day on which the injury or disease was aggravated.

Subsection.Text: The amount of the death benefit payable in respect of a member shall be the amount set out in column 2 of item 3 of Schedule 2.

If an amount is paid or payable to a person from a prescribed source in respect of a death for which a death benefit is payable, the Minister may reduce the death benefit payable to the person by a prescribed amount.

Section.Text: If a death benefit is payable to a survivor or a person who was, at the time of a member’s death, a dependent child, the following rules apply:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if there is a survivor but no person who was a dependent child, the survivor is entitled to 100% of the death benefit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if there is a survivor and one or more persons who were dependent children,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the survivor is entitled to 50% of the death benefit, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the persons who were dependent children are entitled, as a class, to 50% of the death benefit, divided equally among them; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if there are one or more persons who were dependent children but no survivor, each of those children is entitled to the amount obtained by dividing the death benefit by the number of those dependent children.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, on application, pay to a member or a veteran who has received a disability award on account of an amputation of their leg at or above a Symes’ amputation a clothing allowance in respect of each such amputation that causes wear and tear of clothing.

The Minister may, on application, pay to a member or a veteran who has received a disability award on account of an amputation of the arm at or above the wrist a clothing allowance in respect of each such amputation that causes wear and tear of clothing.

If a member or a veteran has received a disability award on account of two amputations of a kind described in subsection (1) or (2), the Minister may, on application, in addition to the allowances that may be payable under that subsection, pay a clothing allowance in respect of the second amputation equal to 50% of the allowance payable in respect of that amputation.

If a member or a veteran has received a disability award for a disability other than a disability described in subsection (1) or (2) that causes wear and tear of clothing, the Minister may, on application, pay a clothing allowance.

If a member or a veteran has received a disability award for a disability that requires the wearing of specially made apparel, the Minister may, on application, in addition to any other allowance that may be payable under this section, pay a clothing allowance on account of the purchase of the apparel.

Section.Text: Subject to subsection 60(3), the Minister shall determine the amount of each clothing allowance that may be paid to a member or a veteran in a year, which shall not be greater than the amount set out in column 2 of item 4 of Schedule 2.
The clothing allowance under subsections 60(1) to (5) begins to be payable on the later of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the application for the allowance was made, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day that is one year prior to the day on which the payment of the allowance is approved.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the rules of evidence and evidentiary presumptions relating to applications for a critical injury benefit, a disability award or a death benefit under this Part.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (5), the Minister may, on application, pay a detention benefit to a member or a veteran, who, while serving with the Canadian Forces, was detained by a power, for the period spent in detention.
In this section, power means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an enemy or an opposing force of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person or a group that has as one of its purposes or activities the facilitating or carrying out of a terrorist activity; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any prescribed entity.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the period spent in detention includes the period during which the member or veteran was engaged in evading capture by, or in escaping from, any power.
The Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing the amount of the detention benefit.
No detention benefit is payable under this section in respect of a period spent in detention if the period began before the coming into force of this section.

Section.MarginalNote: Death of member or veteran — no application made

Subsection.Text: If a member or a veteran who would have been entitled to a detention benefit under section 64 dies before they have applied for the benefit, the Minister may, on application, pay to their testamentary estate or testamentary succession the detention benefit to which the member or veteran, had they lived, would have been entitled under that section.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Death of member or veteran — application pending
Subsection.Text: If a member or a veteran who has made an application for a detention benefit under section 64 dies before the Minister has made a decision in respect of the application, the Minister may pay to their testamentary estate or testamentary succession the detention benefit to which the member or veteran, had they lived, would have been entitled under that section.
The testamentary estate or testamentary succession has, in respect of the application referred to in subsection (2), all of the rights that the member or veteran would have had had they lived.
The Minister may, on application, pay a family caregiver relief benefit to a veteran if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they have had an application for a disability award approved under section 45;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: as a result of the disability for which the application for a disability award was approved, they require ongoing care;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is 18 years of age or older plays an essential role in the provision or coordination of the ongoing care in the veteran’s home for which the person receives no remuneration; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the veteran meets the prescribed eligibility requirements.

Subsection.Text: In deciding whether the veteran requires ongoing care, the Minister shall consider only prescribed criteria.

In deciding whether the person referred to in paragraph (1)(c) plays an essential role in the provision or coordination of the ongoing care in the veteran’s home, the Minister shall consider only prescribed factors.
A veteran who is eligible for an attendance allowance under subsection 38(1) of the Pension Act is not eligible for a family caregiver relief benefit.

Section.Text: The annual amount of a family caregiver relief benefit that is payable to a veteran shall be the amount set out in column 2 of item 5 of Schedule 2.

The Minister may, for the purpose of determining whether a veteran may continue to receive a family caregiver relief benefit, require the veteran to undergo an assessment by a person specified by the Minister.
The Governor in Council may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: defining care for the purposes of paragraphs 65.1(1)(b) and (c) and subsections 65.1(2) and (3); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: defining home for the purposes of paragraph 65.1(1)(c) and subsection 65.1(3).

Subsection.Text: The Minister may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establish or enter into a contract to acquire a group insurance program compa­rable to the Public Service Health Care Plan established by the Treasury Board;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to the approval of the Treasury Board, set any terms and conditions in respect of the program, including those respecting the premiums or the contributions payable, the benefits and the management and control of the program;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: make the contributions and pay the premiums or the benefits, as required; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: undertake and do all things that the Minister considers appropriate for the purpose of implementing and maintaining the program.

Subsection.Text: A member, a veteran or a member’s or a veteran’s survivor may elect to participate in a group insurance program referred to in subsection (1) if they meet the prescribed eligibility requirements.
Subject to subsection (2), the Minister may designate any person to exercise any power or perform any duty or function that may be exercised or performed by the Minister under this Act.
If the Minister designates a person to make a decision under this Act, the Minister may not designate the same person to review the decision.

Section.MarginalNote: Definition of conditions of elevated risk
